**M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28**.proposition: Under **M.G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a modification of custody or visitation may be made "upon a showing that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the modification is necessary in the best interests of the children."

**M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20**.proposition: Since entry of the April 15, 2021 order, there has been a **material and substantial change in circumstances** within the meaning of **M.G.L. c. 208, § 28** and **M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20**.

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: **M.G.L. c. 215, § 6** grants the Probate and Family Court equitable authority to modify its prior judgments as justice and equity require.

**M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31**.proposition: **M.G.L. c. 208, § 31** defines “shared legal custody” and “physical custody” and authorizes the Court to modify custodial arrangements consistent with the children’s best interests.

**Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)*.proposition: The Court’s primary consideration in any custody determination is the **best interests of the child**, as established in **Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)**.
**Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)*.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly identifies the “best interests of the child” as the governing standard in custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and situates that standard within longstanding Massachusetts jurisprudence. The court describes the best-interests inquiry as the ‘touchstone’ and ‘paramount concern’ in custody matters, confirming that this is the primary consideration in deciding custody. Thus, the case is accurately cited for the proposition stated.
**Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)*.relevant_excerpt:
“Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ …

In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: In **Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)**, the Appeals Court held that a significant change affecting the child’s daily wellbeing may warrant modification even if each parent remains fit.
**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The court’s analysis focuses on two questions: (1) whether there was a material and substantial change in circumstances sufficient to modify custody, and (2) whether the custodial parent could relocate. The Appeals Court holds there was *no* material and substantial change warranting modification and reverses the transfer of custody; it does not hold that a significant change in the child’s daily wellbeing can itself justify modification where both parents remain fit. The opinion emphasizes that the original custody award is presumed correct and that nothing after the divorce sufficiently altered circumstances to justify changing custody, which is the opposite of the claimed proposition.
**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements which, on all of the uncontested evidence, had been in place with no ill effect on the child since the parties’ separation in October, 1995. … The judgment modifying custody must be reversed.”

**Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395.proposition: **Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985)** and **Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)** emphasize the importance of stability, continuity, and the child’s overall wellbeing over parental convenience.
**Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395.support_reasoning: Yannas focuses on the removal standard and the linkage between the custodial parent’s well‑being and the child’s best interests, not expressly on “stability and continuity” versus “parental convenience.” The opinion balances the custodial parent’s legitimate reasons for relocation against the impact on the child and the noncustodial parent’s visitation, and even says the custodial parent’s interest must be considered—not subordinated as mere convenience. Thus, while related to child well‑being, it does not clearly stand for the proposition that stability and continuity override parental convenience in the way described.
**Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395.relevant_excerpt: “An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: **Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985)** and **Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)** emphasize the importance of stability, continuity, and the child’s overall wellbeing over parental convenience.
**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the removal inquiry under G.L. c. 208, § 30 as a pure best‑interests‑of‑the‑child analysis, and in the joint‑custody context it stresses maintaining the child’s relationships with both parents, minimizing disruption, and considering school, developmental, and emotional needs. The court affirms denial of removal because uprooting would be detrimental educationally and socially and would reduce the father’s parenting time, making clear that the children’s stability, continuity, and welfare outweigh the relocating parent’s preferences or convenience. This aligns with the stated proposition about emphasizing stability and overall wellbeing over parental convenience.
**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children taking into account all the circumstances… Where physical custody is shared… the child’s interests will typically ‘favor protection of the child’s relationships with both parents because both are, in a real sense, primary to the child’s development.’… From this the judge determined that it was not in the children’s best interests to be removed to Bristol.”

**Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: **Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996)** and **Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976)** make clear that the trial court must reassess custody when new facts show that circumstances have materially changed in a way that affects the children’s welfare.
**Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: Custody of Vaughn concerns the need for explicit findings on the impact of domestic violence when making a custody award and authorizes a remand for additional findings, but it does not articulate the general "material change of circumstances" standard or require reassessment of custody upon new facts. The opinion mentions that three years had passed and that the judge may re‑interview the child and consider the success of the interim arrangement, but this is framed as what "may be appropriate," not as a rule that new, materially changed circumstances affecting welfare mandate a reassessment. Thus, it does not clearly support the specific proposition for which it is cited.
**Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above. … As almost three years have gone by since the Probate Court issued its judgment and Vaughn is now almost fourteen years of age, it may be appropriate for the judge to interview the child again as to his preference and for the judge to evaluate the success of the stipulated custody arrangement the parties have been living under in the interim.”

**Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.proposition: **Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996)** and **Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976)** make clear that the trial court must reassess custody when new facts show that circumstances have materially changed in a way that affects the children’s welfare.
**Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.support_reasoning: Vilakazi is a straight best‑interests-of-the-child custody decision reviewing whether the probate judge abused his discretion on the facts before him. The opinion does not discuss the standard or requirement for later *reassessment* or *modification* of custody orders upon a material change in circumstances; it merely notes in passing that custody orders may be subject to future modification and cites the relevant statute and other cases for that point. Thus, Vilakazi does not itself “make clear” that a trial court must reassess custody when new facts show a material change affecting the child’s welfare.
**Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.relevant_excerpt: “We hold that the judge correctly applied these principles in deciding this case and that on the facts found and reported by him he did not abuse his discretion. As to the circumstances in which orders for the custody of minor children may be subject to future modification by the court see G. L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30, Palmer v. Palmer, 357 Mass. 764 (1970), and Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 550 (1930).”

**Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)**.proposition: **Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)** reaffirms that the child’s best interests are paramount, and a parent’s changing work conditions can constitute a material change.
**Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)**.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly reiterates that in custody matters the ‘touchstone inquiry’ is what is best for the child and applies that standard throughout its custody analysis, thereby reaffirming that the child’s best interests are paramount. It also treats the comparative stability and flexibility of each parent’s work schedule—including Rose’s decision to accept a residency with ‘extraordinarily long hours’ in another state—as a key factor in the best-interests determination, recognizing work conditions as part of the material circumstances justifying the custody arrangement. While the case is not a classic ‘modification’ decision, it clearly uses changing work conditions as an important custody factor.
**Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)**.relevant_excerpt:
“‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ … Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule….
…[T]he judge found that a move to Michigan would put Jill ‘in an unfamiliar environment with new caregivers and … medical providers’ while Rose worked ‘extraordinary long hours as a medical resident for the next four years.’”

**Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 32.proposition: **Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325 (2010)** and **Sullivan v. Sullivan, 466 Mass. 886 (2014)** together confirm that when a parenting plan fails to meet a child’s current needs due to a parent’s work constraints, modification serves the child’s best interest.
**Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 32.support_reasoning: Charara concerns international comity and whether to defer to a Lebanese religious custody decree under G.L. c. 209B; it does not address modification of an existing Massachusetts parenting plan based on a parent’s work constraints or evolving needs of the child. The opinion discusses the Massachusetts ‘best interests of the child’ standard only in the context of comparing it to Lebanese law and deciding whether to recognize the foreign order, not in the context of modifying a parenting plan for changed circumstances such as work schedules. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific modification principle stated in the proposition.
**Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 32.relevant_excerpt: “The best interests of a child is the overarching principle that governs custody disputes in the Commonwealth… What is in a child’s best interest depends upon the particular needs of the child, and is left largely to the discretion of the judge, who ‘may consider any factor pertinent to those interests.’ … The best interests analysis our courts employ is thus unlike the presumptive entitlement to custody that governed the custody proceeding in the Jaafarite Court in Lebanon. The custody judgment of that court is therefore not in substantial conformity with the laws of the Commonwealth.”

**Sullivan v. Sullivan, 466 Mass. 886 (2.proposition: **Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325 (2010)** and **Sullivan v. Sullivan, 466 Mass. 886 (2014)** together confirm that when a parenting plan fails to meet a child’s current needs due to a parent’s work constraints, modification serves the child’s best interest.
